meeting_sections.section_name: HEARINGS: ITEMS NOT ON THE AGENDA (The Board does not take action or respond to items not on the agenda.)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Revised board policy 2340 (formerly 9128) concerning board meeting agendas was presented for review and first reading at the December 9, 2013, meeting. A change to the policy title was suggested at the meeting and has been incorporated in the attachment. The recommended revisions clarify the circumstances under which the Board may act on items not on the agenda, move sections regarding addressing the governing board to new policies concerning speakers (BP 2350) and decorum (BP 2355), and bring the policy into alignment with the language and numbering system of the Community College League of California's (CCLC) Policy and Procedure Service. Added language is indicated on the attachment by bold, underlined text, while deleted text is represented by strikethrough. A newly approved administrative procedure developed to implement the policy is included for information.
	 
The Chancellor's Advisory Council approved the revised board policy and new administrative procedure electronically by consensus on October 18, 2013. 
	 
References:
Education Code Sections 72121, 72121.5
Government Code Sections 54954 et seq., 6250 et seq.
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends adoption of revised board policy 2340 Board Meeting Agendas.
items.item_text: Board Policy 2340 (formerly 9128) Board Meeting Agendas - Revised (Second Reading)
items.item_text_raw: 1. Board Policy 2340 (formerly 9128) Board Meeting Agendas - Revised (Second Reading)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Revisions to board policy 2345 (formerly 1130) concerning Government Code requirements for public participation at governing board meetings were presented for first reading at the December 9, 2013, Board of Trustees meeting. A reference to board policy 2355 concerning board meeting decorum has been added to the draft policy pursuant to feedback received at the meeting. The proposed changes conform to the Community College League of California's Policy and Procedure Service templates and numbering system. New language is indicated on the attachment by bold, underlined text, while deleted text is represented by strikethrough. 
	 
The Chancellor's Advisory Council approved the revised board policy electronically by consensus on October 18, 2013. 
	 
References:
Education Code Sections 72121.5
Government Code Sections 54954.3 and 54957.5
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Proposed new board policy 2350 regarding speakers was presented for review and first reading at the December 9, 2013, meeting. Based on input received at the meeting, the title has been changed to clarify that the policy applies to governing board meetings only. The new policy sets forth legal and procedural conditions for addressing the governing board and includes language that was previously part of board policy 2340 (formerly 9128) Board Meeting Agendas.
	 
The Chancellor's Advisory Council approved the new board policy electronically by consensus on October 18, 2013. 
	 
References:
Education Code Sections 72121.5
Government Code Sections 54950
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Proposed new board policy 2355 regarding decorum was presented for review and first reading at the December 9, 2013, meeting. Based on input received at the meeting, the title has been changed to indicate that the policy applies specifically to governing board meetings. The new policy outlines expectations of proper conduct at governing board meetings and includes language that was previously part of board policy 2340 (formerly 9128) Board Meeting Agendas.
	 
The Chancellor's Advisory Council approved the new board policy electronically by consensus on October 18, 2013. 
	 
References:
Education Code Sections 72121.5
Government Code Sections 54954.3(b)
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District has three vehicles that have been replaced (see attached Surplus Forms, 3 pages). The Associate Director of Facilities and Operations has determined that the vehicles are of no further use to the District. The estimated aggregate market value of the vehicles is greater than $5,000.00.  
	 
In accordance with Education Code section 81450, the Board must sell the property to the highest responsible bidder or reject all bids. The code also requires the sale to be advertised at least once a week for two weeks. 
	 
Purchasing Services will advertise the sale, call for competitive bids on the Public Surplus website and sell each vehicle to the highest responsible bidder. Proceeds will be deposited to the District General Fund. 
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, to sell the vehicles to the highest responsible bidder in accordance with Education Code Section 81450.
items.item_text: Sale of Surplus Vehicles
items.item_text_raw: 7. Sale of Surplus Vehicles

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
 
  
 The District has six pallets of computers, monitors, printers, and miscellaneous electronic equipment (see attached Surplus Forms, 7 pages).  The District’s Educational Technology Services Department (ETS) staff has determined that the items are obsolete and of no further use to the District.  In accordance with the Electronic Waste Recycling Act, these items are considered electronic waste. The estimated aggregate market value of this electronic equipment is less than $5,000.00.
	 
California Education Code 81452(a) provides that if the governing board by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, whether one or more items, does not exceed in value the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the property may be sold by any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board. 
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Purchasing Services will post a notice on Bid Net and call for competitive bids from authorized State of California material handlers, collectors, and recyclers. Proceeds will be deposited to the Districtâs general fund.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill seeks board approval for application to the State Chancellor's Office for the associate
	degree for transfer. This degree meets the requirements established by the State Chancellor’s
	Office in response to SB 1440 to establish a means of simplifying student movement within and
	between the segments of higher education in California.
The Associate in Science in Business Administration for Transfer Degree prepares students to
	transfer to local California State Universities (CSUs). Students who complete the Associate in
	Science in Business Administration for Transfer Degree will be ensured preferential transfer
	status to local CSUs for Business Administration majors and/or majors in related disciplines. The
	Associate in Science in Business Administration for Transfer Degree requirements will fulfill the
	lower division major requirements at many local CSUs. Students are advised, however, to meet
	with a counselor to assess the course requirements for specific local CSUs and to validate which
	CSUs are considered local.
The Associate in Science in Business Administration for Transfer Degree will enable students to
	develop theoretical and functional skills specific to many of the primary functions in business
	such as marketing, accounting, finance, and management. Additionally, students will learn
	communication, interpersonal, collaboration, research, critical thinking, and leadership skills
	through hands-on projects.
The new degree has been approved by Foothill's curriculum committee.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy Miner
Additional contact names:
Kimberlee Messina, Isaac Escoto
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: The Foothill College Administration recommends approval of the Associate in Science in Business Administration for Transfer Degree (AS-T) Program.
items.item_text: Foothill College - Approval of Associate in Science Degree in Business Administration for Transfer
items.item_text_raw: 10. Foothill College - Approval of Associate in Science Degree in Business Administration for Transfer

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill seeks board approval for application to the State Chancellor's Office for the associate
	degree for transfer. This degree meets the requirements established by the State Chancellor’s
	Office in response to SB 1440 to establish a means of simplifying student movement within and
	between the segments of higher education in California.
The study of Art History provides the student with an awareness of art, economic, political,
	religious and social history, an increased sensitivity to art-related issues and the ability to think
	critically about art and Art History. Knowledge of Art History engenders a heightened
	understanding of history, a familiarity with the major issues in human cultural development and
	the exposure to the artistic expression of varied cultures and civilizations.
Students who complete the Associate in Arts in Art History for Transfer Degree will be ensured
	preferential transfer status to local CSUs for Art History majors and majors in related disciplines.
	The Associate in Arts in Art History for Transfer Degree requirements will fulfill the lower
	division requirements at local CSUs. Students are advised, however, to meet with a counselor to
	assess the course requirements for specific local CSUs to validate which CSUs are considered
	local.
The new degree has been approved by Foothill's curriculum committee.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy Miner
Additional contact names:
Kimberlee Messina, Isaac Escoto
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: The Foothill College Administration recommends approval of the Associate in Arts in Art History for Transfer Degree (AA-T) Program.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill seeks board approval for application to the State Chancellor's Office for the associate
	degree for transfer. This degree meets the requirements established by the State Chancellor’s
	Office in response to SB 1440 to establish a means of simplifying student movement within and
	between the segments of higher education in California.
The Associate in Arts in Kinesiology for Transfer Degree will provide students with a strong
	foundation in the interdisciplinary academic study of human movement, physical activity and
	sport and prepare students to transfer to California State Universities (CSUs).
Students who complete the Associate in Arts in Kinesiology for Transfer Degree will be ensured
	preferential transfer status to CSUs as Kinesiology majors and/or majors in related disciplines.
	The Associate in Arts in Kinesiology for Transfer Degree requirements will fulfill the lower
	division major requirements at many CSUs. Students are advised, however, to meet with a
	counselor to assess the course requirements for specific CSUs. Graduates will have a solid
	foundation in Kinesiology principles, anatomy and physiology, movement skills, selected
	business and/or science or health options to pursue upper division course work.
	 
The new degree has been approved by Foothill's curriculum committee.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy Miner
Additional contact names:
Kimberlee Messina, Isaac Escoto
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: The Foothill College Administration recommends approval of the Associate in Arts in Kinesiology for Transfer Degree (AA-T) Program.

items.item_text_raw: 12. Foothill College - Approval of Associate in Arts Degree in Kinesiology for Transfer

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Celebrity Forum Speaker Series has been a part of Foothill College for 46 years. The series is an important community event and draws thousands of people each year to Flint Center. From its founding in 1968, the series has been completely self-supporting and has never used District or college funds for its operation, being financed solely through ticket sales. The series has always been a financial success and has contributed valuable discretionary dollars to Foothill College.
	 
The Foothill College Celebrity Forum has secured November 19, 20, 21, 2014 for lectures by Robert Gates through his representative at Washington Speakers Bureau. The agreed upon fee for the three appearances is $195,000. This fee does not include travel expenses. Half of this fee will be used as a deposit to lock in Robert Gates’ appearances and is due immediately.  The remaining half will be due before his actual appearances in November.
	 
This item is being submitted to the board for contract approval.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy Miner
Additional contact names:
Richard Henning, Bernata Slater
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: The Foothill College Administration recommends the approval of the Celebrity Forum contract.
items.item_text: Foothill College - Celebrity Forum Contract Approval
items.item_text_raw: 13. Foothill College - Celebrity Forum Contract Approval

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
At the October 7, 2013, Board of Trustees meeting, trustees were advised that the terms of the at large, taxpayers' association, business organization, and district support organization representatives serving on of the Measure C Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee would terminate at the end of 2013.  It was later determined that the student representative position would also need to be filled. Members of the committee are required to live within the district's service area and may not be an employee, contractor, consultant, or vendor of the district. 
	 
Between October 4 and November 15 (November 30 for student applications), the district solicited candidate applications through advertisements in the Los Altos Town Crier, Cupertino Courier, San Jose Mercury News, Mountain View Voice, and Palo Alto Weekly; a press release sent to local news outlets and posted on the district web site; and announcements sent to chambers of commerce, taxpayers' associations, the Foothill-De Anza Foundation, district advisory councils, and student organizations. Following the deadline, all applications received were reviewed by the Chancellor in consultation with the Board President. The following candidates are recommended for appointment to two-year terms:
	 
Business Organization Representative
Dudley Andersen (Reappointment to third term)
Dr. Dudley Andersen, who currently chairs the district's Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee, has more than 35 years experience in strategic and financial management in both the private and public sectors as a financial advisor, corporate executive, and business founder. 
	 
Taxpayers' Association Representative
Robert Lancefield (Reappointment to third term)
Robert Lancefield, a member of Taxpayers for Common Sense, has operated his own civil law practice, worked in the legal department of Consolidated Freightways, and been active in real estate property management for the past 40 years. His extensive community activities include board membership on the Charter Oak Foundation, which makes grants to at-risk youth.
	 
At Large Representative
Ellen Saliba (New appointment)
Ellen Saliba has over 30 years of financial and operational experience in the computer industry, national and local nonprofit volunteer experience, and a master's degree in business administration. Her professional experience includes work in budget development and strategic planning for multiple Silicon Valley start ups. As a volunteer, she has served as a member of the Los Altos Citizens Finance Advisory Committee and Ad Hoc Grant Writing Committee, president and treasurer of the National Board of Directors of the National Charity League, Inc., and as a Babson College trustee.
	 
Foothill-De Anza Support Organization Representative
Kelly Davis (New appointment)
A regional manager at Heritage Bank of Commerce, Kelly Davis has over 30 years of experience in the financial services industry. She is a member of the Board of Directors of the Foothill-De Anza Foundation and has also served the community as a board member of the Red Cross and The Los Altos Village Association. 
	 
Student Representative
Evelynn Chun (New appointment)
Evelynn Chun is an Associated Students of Foothill College senator in her first year at Foothill College. She recently completed a summer internship with Congressman Mike Honda's campaign, and during her years Homestead High School, she served in various leadership positions in the school's Interact community service club.
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
No

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Trustee Laura Casas serves on the board of the California Community Colleges Trustees (CCCT) and is eligible for an additional term when her current term ends in spring 2014. In order to run for re-election to the CCCT board, she must be nominated by the Foothill-De Anza Community College District governing board. Attached is the official nomination form, which must be submitted by February 15.
	 
The election will occur between March 10 and April 25, election results will be announced at the CCCT annual conference, and elected members will assume their responsibilities at the conclusion of the annual conference on May 4, 2014.  
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends that the Board of Trustees nominate trustee Laura Casas as a candidate for the California Community College Trustees Board.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Proposed revisions to board policy 2110 (formerly 9111) regarding vacancies on the governing board are presented for review and first reading. The revisions set forth the legal requirements for filling a Board vacancy and bring the district's policy in line with the language and numbering system of the Community College League of California Policy and Procedure Service templates. Added language is indicated on the attachment by bold, underlined text, while deleted text is represented by strikethrough. A newly approved administrative procedure developed to implement the policy is attached for reference.
	 
The Chancellor's Advisory Council approved the revised policy and new procedure electronically on October 18, 2013. The revised policy will be presented for approval at the February 3, 2014, regular meeting of the Board of Trustees.
	 
References:
Education Code Section 5090
Government Code Section 1770
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Proposed new board policy 2200 incorporates the Board’s previously approved mission, philosophy, and roles and responsibility statements into policy. The Community College League of California suggests that adopting a policy regarding board duties and responsibilities is a good practice in line with accreditation standards. 
	 
The Chancellor's Advisory Council approved the new policy on November 15, 2013. The policy will be presented for governing board adoption at the February 3, 2014, regular meeting.
	 
References:
Accreditation Standard IV.B.1.d

Linda Thor

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Revised board policy 2220 (formerly 9122) regarding committees established by the governing board is presented for review and first reading. The proposed revisions add language specifying the circumstances under which a committee is subject to open meeting laws, clarifies the nature of the committees previously established by the governing board, and deletes language moved to new board policy 6740 regarding the Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee. Added language is indicated on the attachment by bold, underlined text, while deleted text is represented by strikethrough. 
	 
The policy was approved by the Chancellor's Advisory Council electronically on October 18, 2013, and will be presented to the governing board for approval at the February 3, 2014, regular meeting.
	 
References:
Government Code Section 54952
Education Code Sections 15278, 15280
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
New board policy 6740 regarding the Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee is presented for review and first reading.  The policy language was moved from board policy 2220 regarding committees established by the board. A newly approved administrative procedure that corresponds to the policy is attached for information.  The procedure is in the process of being revised to reflect the recent change to the committee bylaws.
	 
The policy and procedure were approved by the Chancellor's Advisory Council on November 15, 2013. The new policy will be presented for governing board approval at the February 3, 2014, regular meeting.
	 
References:
Education Code Sections 15278, 15280, 15282
California Constitution Article XIIIA Section 1(b), Article XVI Section 18(b)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Provisions with SB 564 require local agencies to report all external investments on a quarterly basis.  In accordance with the aforementioned requirement, attached is a listing of the District’s investments as of September 30, 2013.
	 
The District’s cash of $236,935,163.49 is invested in the County’s Commingled Investments Pool.  As of on September 30, 2013, the current yield on the commingled investments pool was 0.54%.  As a comparison to the same time period, the yield on a two-year Treasury Note was 0.32%; the yield on a 6-month Treasury Bill was 0.03%; and the State of California Local Agency Investment Fund (LAIF) yield was 0.25%.
	 
Submitted by:
					 Kevin McElroy, x6202
Additional contact names:
 Hector Quinonez
Is backup provided?
 Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Title:  Amendment #2 to Memorandum of Agreement
Vendor:  US Department of Veteran Affairs
Agreement Date:  April 4, 2013
Campus:  FHDA Education Center/Onizuka Air Force Station
Project Number:  801
Project Name:  Property Acquisition
Amount:  $300,000 (payable to District)
For:
	 
A change in the Memorandum of Understanding with the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to share utility infrastructure costs and to establish utility easements.  
	 
Where it is advantageous to coordinate efforts with the VA, the District will construct new utilities and alter existing utilities serving both the District’s parcel and the VA’s parcel, and will be reimbursed by the VA for its portion of the improvements. 
	 
The District will grant easements to the City of Sunnyvale (for domestic water and reclaimed water lines) and to PG&E (for gas and electric lines) for future maintenance or repair of the lines entering or crossing the District’s parcel.  Some of these utilities (both new and existing) must cross the District’s parcel to serve the VA parcel because of the way the Air Force divided the land into separate parcels.  
	 
This Amendment increases the agreement amount to allow the VA to reimburse the District for the cost of utilities serving the VA’s parcel and the related design and management costs.  
	 
Submitted by:
Charles Allen, Executive Director, Facilities, Operations, and Construction Management, extension 6150
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Director, Bond Program Management, Foothill College
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approval
items.item_text: US Department of Veteran Affairs - Amendment #2 - Property Acquisition - $300,000
items.item_text_raw: A) US Department of Veteran Affairs - Amendment #2 - Property Acquisition - $300,000

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In August 2013 the District issued a notice inviting sealed bids for Nursing Patient Simulation System, ITB#1474. The District received responses from two bidders – Laerdale Medical Corporation (Laerdale) and CAE Healthcare (CAE). Laerdale submitted a bid for the exact system specified by the District and CAE submitted a bid for a system that was stated to meet or exceed the District’s specifications. CAE was determined to be the lowest responsive and  responsible bidder by the District, and on October 7, 2013, the BOT authorized the award of ITB#1474 to CAE in the amount of $106,643.35. 
	 
On October 10, 2013, the District received a protest letter from Laerdale, the unsuccessful bidder. The protest letter claimed that the awarded product offered by CAE did not fully meet the requirements listed in the District’s bid document. The protest letter was received by the Purchasing Services Department prior to a purchase order being issue to CAE.
	 
After receiving the protest letter, and seeking the advice of the District’s legal counsel John Shupe, the District provided CAE with the opportunity to identify in writing how its product meets or exceeds each of the areas that were identified as non-conforming in the bid protest letter. CAE responded and stated that its product conforms to all specifications listed in the protest letter with the exception of diaphoresis, ear secretions, and circumoral cyanosis. The exceptions were not listed in CAE’s bid documents as required in section 1.04.
	 
Based on the new information of the exceptions the Purchasing Department, together with the Nursing Department, reevaluated the bids and determined that CAE’s system does not meet the minimum specifications as required, and to that extent its bid is non-responsive.
	 
After reviewing the documents and sequence of events with the District’s legal counsel John Shupe, the Director of Purchasing Services sent a letter to CAE Healthcare informing the company of the recommendations that will be taken to the Board of Trustees. The letter requested a response by December 2, 2013, and no response was received.    
	 
The amount of this purchase that will be funded through Measure C FF&E is $110,249.75 and the extended warranty amount of $11,395.25 will be funded from the Nursing Alumni Association.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Dr. Anita Muthyala-Kandula, Dean of Biology, Health, Environmental Sciences and Workforce Development 
Is backup provided?
Yes
